citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* One Adult Bichon Frise (microchip # 933041000049962) has a wound on its right-side rib area. The wound was raw with
exposed moist, pink underlying tissue and black scab-like tissue in the center and around the bottom edge. The wound
was approximately 2 by 3 inches in size. There was discharge in the fur surrounding the wound. At the time of inspection,
the attending veterinarian had not been consulted. The licensee stated they first observed the open wound during today’s
facility inspection. A wound left untreated can lead to further infections, unnecessary pain, itching and distress, delay the
healing process and can attract flies to the affected area. The licensee must have this animal examined by a licensed
veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and treatment of the affected area. Medical records must be made available to the
inspector upon request. The licensee must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care to ensure the health
and well-being of the dogs. Correct by end of business 9/20/24.

* The USDA Vet Care form 7002 A was incomplete for 68 dogs. Under Section B "Parasite Control Program", sampling
plans for Blood and Intestinal Parasites, there is no specific frequency noted for sampling dogs for intestinal parasites
(fecal float). Testing for intestinal parasites is an important element in evaluating the health and wellbeing of the dogs and
must be completed on an annual basis. A completed program of veterinary care must include a parasite testing schedule
for the dogs. This schedule must be approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 11/14/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
MARGARET SHAVER, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
* One Adult Bichon Frise (microchip # 933041000049962) has a wound on its right-side rib area. The wound was raw with 
exposed moist, pink underlying tissue and black scab-like tissue in the center and around the bottom edge. The wound 
was approximately 2 by 3 inches in size. There was discharge in the fur surrounding the wound. At the time of inspection, 
the attending veterinarian had not been consulted. The licensee stated they first observed the open wound during today’s 
facility inspection. A wound left untreated can lead to further infections, unnecessary pain, itching and distress, delay the 
healing process and can attract flies to the affected area. The licensee must have this animal examined by a licensed 
veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and treatment of the affected area. Medical records must be made available to the 
inspector upon request. The licensee must ensure that all animals receive adequate veterinary care to ensure the health 
and well-being of the dogs. Correct by end of business 9/20/24. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The USDA Vet Care form 7002 A was incomplete for 68 dogs. Under Section B "Parasite Control Program", sampling 
plans for Blood and Intestinal Parasites, there is no specific frequency noted for sampling dogs for intestinal parasites 
(fecal float). Testing for intestinal parasites is an important element in evaluating the health and wellbeing of the dogs and 
must be completed on an annual basis. A completed program of veterinary care must include a parasite testing schedule 
for the dogs. This schedule must be approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 11/14/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MARGARET SHAVER, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
